Appointment 02122.
Appointment of Michelle Mitchell-Brannon as a member of the city light review panel for a term to April 11, 2024.
Brief discussion and possible vote.

This is our first appointment in this Committee.
I'm happy to support the appointment of Michelle Mitchell-Brannon to the Seattle city light review panel.

Thank you Councilmember Nelson and the rest of the committee.
We are super excited to be here today.
I haven't met you, I am Debra Smith the general manager at Seattle city light.

A lot of her work has been focused on youth in various ways.
Having the additional perspective on the review panel, which isn't identified community of interest but as we are in this transition about so many things, I think that will be incredibly important.
I am really excited about this appointment and I wanted to introduce Leigh Barreca, you guys by now know I struggle with titles.

I just have a couple of slides that Maura Brueger is going to run to give a quick overview of the city light review panel.
You can go forward.
Just a reminder about what the review panel is.
The review panel was created in 2010 per city ordinance.
City light previously had a city light advisory board and also a rate advisory committee.
The city light review panel combined the duties of both groups.
In 2015 there were some minor adjustments made to their scope and process to their charter and that was passed with yet another ordinance.
Per charter ordinance, the review panels activities or role are advisory to city light on our strategic plan, the development and plan itself as well as the accompanying path.
The review panel, each time a plan is submitted, they provide an opinion to the city council on the merits of the plan, to the city Council and Mayor.
And 420 22, right now we are working on an update to the strategic plan, to the 2022 plan.
That would be delivered to the Council in June.
So the panel is working, we are working very closely with the panel through the development of that update.
Excuse me.
Next slide, please.
We have nine members on the panel.

Four appointed by the Mayor, five appointed by the Mayor, excuse me, and each serves a staggered three-year term although at the conclusion of their three-year term, panel members are eligible to serve a second term.
As you can see the nine members are intentionally directed to serve certain parts of our customer base.

We have an economist, financial analyst, nonprofit energy efficiency representative, commercial customer Rep, residential Rep, industrial, a member at large and a representative from one of our Uburban trench I cities.
Position number seven--we are so happy right now with this appointment, we will have a full panel which is something we have been working on for quite some time.
Position number seven is the low income customer representative.
With that, I am pleased to announce, to introduce Michele to speak with you.
Thank you.
I am so excited to be here and be part of this appointment.
A little about me, I am born and raised in Seattle in the central district.
Grandmother was in the city as well as my grandfather we started servitude very early on in age.
To work within the African- American and low-income communities is definitely a privilege and an honor for me.
I am excited to be able to lend the voice of the community to this position and to the work so we are informed about making the best decisions for those that will be impacted.
Again, I am excited.
I have been doing this for over 20 years.
And yes, I can't explain to you that I can't wait to get to work on this whole panel and definitely give, again, voice to a community I'm so privileged and love to serve.
Thank you.
Thank you very much, Michelle.
It is wonderful to meet you.
You for your service.

I am a director of education and youth development education support at Atlantic Street center which is an organization that has been around just a few years.
Working in the central district and South end of Seattle.
Some of the programs I am privileged to run our youth Afterschool programs which is the Preventative supports of youth that are at risk.
Also teen parents.
And for those of you that haven't seen it in the Seattle times, six years we have been in the Seattle times about the work I have been fortunate to be able to do with the teen as parents program.
Also I have the kinship care providers which are kinship providers taking care of their Great-Grandchildren or relative kids.
That is a program I run.
And a huge young parent program were we going to the homes and remove any barriers around people getting connected to supports and employment.
Housing.
A lot of the families we work with our 100% low income . Some are, 65% are homeless or and Stably housed.
That is the work I do every day that I am privileged to do and work alongside Partnering with families so that they can change the trajectory of their lives.
Allowing them to inform us.
So the programs are designed to meet their needs.
That is what I do on my day today.
Thank you very much for that.
You are a very busy person.
And in serving on this panel, it is a great responsibility.
So thank you very much for giving of your time in service and expertise.

Good morning, chair Nelson and Council members.

My name is Mike steward executive director of Ballard alliance business improvement area that represents hundreds of businesses that focus on among other things marketing and tourism to drive visitors to Seattle and the Ballard neighborhood.
I'm here today to voice support for the Seattle tourism improvement area and the rate change that will allow the city to thrive and maintain competitive position among other destinations.
Fees generated by paid guests in downtown hotels, marketing effort celebrate the diversity across the city and region including neighborhood business districts like Ballard.
Supporting campaigns and events, that really help illustrate how people are inspired to explore via neighborhoods.
Many of our alliance members and partner businesses have been featured in campaigns which serve as a advertising onto their business for neighborhood.

The Ballard alliance has also developed its partnership with Seattle over the past several years and our local independent small businesses from high-end restaurants, cultural organizations to craft breweries have greatly benefited from collaborative marketing programs and events.
Really is a Symbiotic relationship between central visit district and the others.
Having a thriving tourism industry with the Seattle central business district will in turn help ensure that Ballard is is is and attractions also thrive.
Increase funding can benefit our small businesses that have been hit the hardest throughout the pandemic.
At a time when it's needed most.
Thank you for your time today and I strongly encourage your approval.
Thank you very much.
Go ahead, Mary.
Good morning.
Can you hear me?
Yes I can.
Sorry about that.

We have our own Council meetings.
This is Mary, executive director of the Pike place Orchid PDA.
I represent over 500 small businesses within the Pike place market community.
As you know it is one of Seattle's most recognizable and popular points of interest.
It is heavily impacted by the is a's of the region.
It helps us thrive with the visitors.
As you know it was very devastated by the pandemic and the loss of those visitors to the region the last couple of years.

As we find ourselves getting out of the pandemic and hopefully starting to move into recovery this ability to bolster our destination advertising, marketing and public relation efforts is very critical right now.
The Stia is a powerful tool and has been in Seattle's long-term recovery.
It supports the small business community that has been so devastated throughout the pandemic.
We really have been struggling to come through and it looks like there is a light at the end of this tunnel.
And they really encourage you to support this.
While already it's a proven success at its existing rate, the ability to increase this assessment to drive tourism where it's needed most doesn't come to the cost of the city of Seattle.

Our small business community in the Pike place market Brickley benefited from the Stia and was supported by campaigns like, I know a place, visit Seattle, all the programs really inspire visitors to explore the artisans, Buskers, farmers, small businesses and Crafters.
Over 500 of them, that by the way were open through the entire pandemic, most throughout the pandemic, this makes the Pike place market the soul of Seattle.
I ask you to approve the Stia legislation so we can drive tourism and economic impact throughout Seattle in an equitable way.
Thank you for your time.
Thank you very much for your comments.
Our last Speaker is Joshua.
Please go ahead.
Good morning.
Can you hear me?
Yes.
Wonderful.
My name is Joshua, and the deputy director.
Thank you for the opportunity to speak in support of the Seattle tourism improvement area.
For culture is King County's cultural development authority.
Our mission is to support a vibrant cultural sector.
We do this by providing grant funding programs to over 500 cultural institutions across the arts, Heritage and historic preservation.
We also support individual artists and culture producers through our national public art program.
We are supported, all this work is supported through County lodge and tax proceeds and 1% for the arts.
And today I am speaking in support because of the revenue it generates we know will help the city and region recover faster.
Already, Stia programs are vital to Seattle's cultural institutions.

In fact, for years an additional grant support to visit Seattle specifically for the Seattle Newseum program which has been a staple program that shines a light on the incredible cultural treasures we have to offer and inspires visitors to explore our vast cultural communities.
Not only in downtown Seattle but throughout the county.
As we begin to move past the height of the pandemic and into recovery, the ability to bolster the arts, has never been more critical.
And Stia has proven to be a tough vehicle in Seattle's long-term recovery because it provides the support that artists and cultural institutions need at the very time we needed the most.
Our research suggests that the cultural sector just in 2020 alone experienced nearly $200 million of revenue losses.
So when we work together to increase Visitation to greater Seattle hundreds of cultural organizations and thousands of cultural producers across King County benefit.
Please approve the Stia legislation so we can radically drive tourism and economic vibrancy drought Seattle and throughout the entire County.
Thank you.
Thank you very much.

Yolanda for Council central staff.
I'm going to provide the process overview.
It is governed by state law and to know where we are in the process.
There are several procedural requirements including two places of legislation there is a resolution that States the city's intent to change the rates.
And describes the proposed change and sets the date and location for hearing.
The proposal must be opted at least 15 days in advance of the hearing.
Than there is also separately an ordinance that would change the assessment rate.
March 1 the Council adopted resolution 32043 stating the city's intent to modify Seattle tourism improvement area assessment rates.
And set the date and location for the public hearing for today March 23, a remote public hearing.
Also required by state law, the city must mail all Ratepayers a copy of the adopted resolution and publish a notice in the Daily Journal of Commerce at least 10 days in advance of the public hearing.
On March 8 the DJ see notice was published and city staff mailed the resolution to Ratepayers.
They should've all received that well in advance of this public hearing.
Council bill 120 272 was recorded to this Committee and is the subject of discussion today.
And possible vote.

Do my colleagues have any questions before we move on?
Councilmember Strauss?
Thank you, chair Nelson and think you Tom and Ali for joining us today.

What has happened between the last committee meeting in today's committee meeting was downtown Seattle Association in town, during that conference there were places that we need to improve downtown and the were some strong highlighted.
It's interesting to see I believe his name was Mr.
Florida who came and spoke about having been downtown 25 years ago and being here today.
We are stronger today than we were 25 years ago.
We have the bones in place to make a destination, not only for Seattleites, not only for the region, but for the entire country and international.
We do have some things we need to work on.
That includes public safety.
I just wanted to raise this because I think that the state of downtown really spoke to this committee meeting and to Stia influence.
And so two points, one I know you spoke about the I know a place and I know I need to come into my Video with you to show you my places.
But, two questions for you, how are you using these dollars to show the world that Seattle is in fact thriving?
And, how are you Partnering with the regional homelessness authority, because for the regional homeless authority to be successful we all have to do a little bit.
It was interesting Ceo doan's noted they are not the county, they're not the city, and that is why they need everyone to participate in the success.
Those are the two kind of Framings of questions.
How are you showing Seattle is thriving and how are you Partnering to help address the homelessness issues?
Thank you, Councilmember.
Like you and I think all of us, I was incredibly inspired last week at the event.
Congratulations Councilmember Nelson on your work on the panel.
I think all of us left that meeting knowing and feeling the optimism and excitement of the city and what is ahead of us as we come through recovery into the next number of years.
Since 2011 Council members, as you know, the Stia has promoting travel to the city and region.

We took a different approach seven or eight years ago as we looked at exploring deeper neighborhoods in the city, small business, business is owned by Bipoc owners, minority, women owned businesses, celebrating everything we have with a slant towards arts and culture, food certainly, and attractions and museums.
So we feel really good about the work we've been doing.
Certainly we know right now the need is more critical than ever.
To continue that work.
And to do it in a much stronger way.
As I have said a number of times, we are going to need to work very hard as a city to earn tourism recovery.
I think especially if you look the last couple of years with negative publicity and things that are sometimes deserved, often not deserved, we are working very hard in all areas to do that.
We are proud of the work we have done and I know you have seen a lot of the work we have done.
Last week I was inspired by the panel and mark's comments from the Rha, I have not met mark, we support the work of that.
We know that has been a missing link in our struggles with how we treat all of the elements around unsheltered people.
I do think, and I am proud of the work that the lodging community has done, directly and indirectly, through taxes and tourism and lodging taxes that had been going for housing.
We know that is a critical element in the equation to get us further ahead in homelessness.
I'm very proud from convention center money being spent to the King County tax in the city and lodging for a large amount, hundreds of millions of dollars to housing.
And certainly the short-term rental tax as you know well in the last couple of years has been directly appropriated to the city for use in different levels of housing.
So, am excited to meet mark, I have not done that yet.
We support the work and know that that is the most critical thing you could be doing as a city.
We are all in that way.
Wonderful, thank you, Tom.

Just noting over the last 25 years, you played a very large role in a lot of the marketing for our city in helping to grow Seattle as a destination which then helps us grow as a city and as you say, indirectly everything is tied.
Congratulations and thank you for all of your work.
I'm not going to wish you a happy retirement it.
Thank you, sir.
Chair Nelson, those are all my questions.
Thank you very much for bringing that up.
I think it is important to see the big picture that in addition to supporting visit Seattle and Stia, hotel and lodging taxes to support a lot of critical needs directly and indirectly.
I do have some numbers, and I'm going to put them forward, just because I feel a sense of urgency of going ahead and acting on this today.
I will have to suspend the rules to do so.

Just what we are talking, the short-term rental tax we're talking about tax on Airbnb's, it funds investment in affordable housing programs and community initiative equitable development projects as determined by the city of Seattle.
Pre-Covid in 2019 it generated $9.4 million . In 2020 it dropped to $3.8 million and in 2021 it was that $6.1 million.
Then there is the King County 2% lodging tax which funds affordable housing and arts and culture at a rate of $37.5 million each for affordable housing.
And arts and culture.
For affordable housing it is projected $559 million over the next 25 years and for arts and cultures, same amount.
$559 million over 25 years.
Finally the Washington state convention center summit building project is $93 million in community investments including nearly $40 million for affordable housing.

Then I will go on to note that the ability for us to promote Seattle as a destination for leisure tourism is important for downtown recovery but also for the whole city as we learned last time, the visit Seattle promotes all neighborhoods of the city and, in doing so helps those businesses all over the city stay in business, grow, server neighborhoods and generate taxes for the city's general fund.
And then we go ahead and support, obviously, many services that are needed by many agencies.
And we do contribute to the regional homeless authority.
So, anyway, I just wanted to make sure that was part of this discussion.
And, I wanted to know if there any other questions or comments on this segment?

I move that the committee recommends passage of Council bill 120273.

And the funding here is so important because the estimated additional $3.5 million for marketing and promotion will fuel extra spending and specifically the hard-hit Industries through efforts coming up that I look for to participating in.
